dialogs.original: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will notopen my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in way of thy excuse.   My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
dialogs.translated: No, either tell me where you've been, or I won't say a word in your defense. My lady Olivia will have you hanged for being absent.

dialogs.original: Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colors.
dialogs.translated: Let her hang me then. A well-hanged (and well-hung) man doesn't need to be afraid of anything he sees.

dialogs.original: Make that good.
dialogs.translated: Explainand clean up your language.

dialogs.original: He shall see none to fear.
dialogs.translated: He'll be dead, and so he won't see anything to be afraid of.

dialogs.original: A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that sayingwas born, of I fear no colors.
dialogs.translated: That's a meager answer. And I can tell you where you got that saying about not being afraid of anything.

dialogs.original: Where, good Mistress Mary?
dialogs.translated: Where, good Mistress Mary?

dialogs.original: In the wars. And that may you be bold to say in your foolery.
dialogs.translated: From soldiers at war. And it's bold of you to talk like a soldier, when you're only a fool.

dialogs.original: Well, God give them wisdom that have it. And those thatare fools, let them use their talents.
dialogs.translated: Well, let God give wisdom to those who have it. Everyone has their talents, and for those of us who are fools, let us use our gifts.

dialogs.original: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.   Or tobe turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?
dialogs.translated: But you'll still be hanged for being gone so long. Or at least fired and kicked out, and wouldn't that be just as bad for you?

dialogs.original: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage,   and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.
dialogs.translated: Sometimes getting hanged saves a man from getting into a bad marriage, and as for getting kicked out, it's summer, so being homeless won't be so bad.

dialogs.original: You are resolute, then?
dialogs.translated: You are firm in your resolve, then?

dialogs.original: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.
dialogs.translated: No, but I am resolved on two points.

dialogs.original: That if one break, the other will hold.   Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.
dialogs.translated: Yesthe two points where your suspenders are buttoned on. If one breaks, the other will hold. But if both break, your pants will fall.

dialogs.original: Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way.   If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece ofEves flesh as any in Illyria.
dialogs.translated: Very clever, really, very clever. Well, go along now. If only Sir Toby would stop drinking, you'd be a woman who was as funny as any person in Illyria.

dialogs.original: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady.Make your excuse wisely, you were best.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, you villain, no more of that. Here comes my lady. It would be best for you if you came up with a good excuse for being gone so long.

dialogs.original: [aside]   Wit, an t be thy will, put me into good fooling!   Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools.   And I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus?   Better awitty fool, than a foolish wit.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Come on, wit, give me something good to say now! Those people who think they're witty often prove to be fools. And I'm sure that I'm not witty, so I might pass for a wise man. For what did the philosopher Quinapalus say? "Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit."

dialogs.original: God bless thee, lady!
dialogs.translated: God's greetings to you, my lady!

dialogs.original: Take the fool away.
dialogs.translated: Take the fool away.

dialogs.original: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.
dialogs.translated: Didn't you hear her, fellows? Take the lady away.

dialogs.original: Go to, youre a dry fool. Ill no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.
dialogs.translated: That's enoughyou're a dull, dry fool. I'm tired of you. Besides, you're getting unreliable.

dialogs.original: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend. For give the dry fool drink, then is the fool notdry.   Bid the dishonest man mend himself. If he mend, heis no longer dishonest.   If he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything thats mended is but patched.   Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue.   If that this simple syllogism will serve, so. If it will not, what remedy?    As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beautys a flower.   The lady bade take away the fool. Therefore, I say again, take her away.
dialogs.translated: My holy lady, these are two flaws that some alcohol and good advice will fix. If you give the dry fool a drink, then the fool won't be dry anymore. And if you give the unreliable man some good advice, then he can mend his ways and won't be unreliable anymore. And if he can't mend his ways, then let the tailor mend him. Anything that's mended is only patched up. A virtuous man who does something wrong is only patched with sin, and a sinner who mends his ways is only patched with virtue. If this logical argument will convince you, then good. But if not, what can be done? The only truly betrayed husband is one deserted by luck, and beauty is a lucky flowerso you won't remain alone for long, my lady. But you gave orders to take away the fool. So I tell you all again, take the lady away.

dialogs.original: Sir, I bade them take away you.
dialogs.translated: Sir, I told them to take you away.

dialogs.original: Misprision in the highest degree!   Lady, Cucullus non facit monachum   thats as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain.   Good madonna, give me leave to proveyou a fool.
dialogs.translated: An error of the worst kind! Lady, don't judge a book by its coverthat's to say that I wear jester's clothes on the outside, but my brain is still sharp. My holy lady, let me prove that you're a fool.

dialogs.original: Can you do it?
dialogs.translated: Can you do it?

dialogs.original: Dexterously, good madonna.
dialogs.translated: Easily, my good lady.

dialogs.original: Make your proof.
dialogs.translated: Then prove it.

dialogs.original: I must catechise you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
dialogs.translated: I must ask you some questions then, my holy lady. Please answer them, my virtuous little mouse.

dialogs.original: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, Ill bide your proof.
dialogs.translated: Well, sir, I have nothing better to do, so I'll go along with this.

dialogs.original: Good madonna, why mournest thou?
dialogs.translated: Dear lady, why are you in mourning?

dialogs.original: Good fool, for my brothers death.
dialogs.translated: Dear fool, because of my brother's death.

dialogs.original: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
dialogs.translated: I think his soul is in hell, lady.

dialogs.original: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
dialogs.translated: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

dialogs.original: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brothers soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.
dialogs.translated: Then you're a fool, holy lady, to mourn your brother's soul being in heaven. Now take away the fool, gentlemen.

dialogs.original: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? Doth he not mend?
dialogs.translated: What do you think of this fool, Malvolio? Hasn't he gotten better?

dialogs.original: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him.    Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
dialogs.translated: Yes, and he will until the day he dies. Old age and senility hurt wise people, but improve fools.

dialogs.original: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!   Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence thatyou are no fool.
dialogs.translated: Then may God send you old age and senility, that you might become a better fool! Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I'm not a clever man, but he wouldn't bet two cents that you're not a fool.

dialogs.original: How say you to that, Malvolio?
dialogs.translated: What do you say to that, Malvolio?

dialogs.original: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.   I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that has no more brain than a stone.   Look you now, hes out of his guard already. Unless you laughand minister occasion to him, he is gagged.   I protest Itake these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
dialogs.translated: I'm surprised that your ladyship enjoys the company of such an empty-headed villain. The other day I saw him lose a battle of wits to an ordinary idiot who had no more brains than a stone. Look at him now, he's without a witty retort already. Unless you laugh and give him an opportunity, he can't think of a thing to say. I declare that the so-called wise men who laugh so hard at these jesters' well-rehearsed routines are no better than jesters' assistants themselves.

dialogs.original: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste witha distempered appetite.   To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets.   There is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail.   Nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.
dialogs.translated: Oh, you're sick with vanity, Malvolio, and it affects your good taste. If you were generous, innocent, and friendly, then you wouldn't make such mountains out of mole-hills. There's no real harm in a professional fool, even if he does nothing but mock people. In the same way there's no real mockery in a wise man, even if he does nothing but criticize people.

dialogs.original: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
dialogs.translated: May Mercurythat god of deceptionmake you a skilled liar, to reward you for speaking so highly of fools!

dialogs.original: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
dialogs.translated: Madam, there's a young gentleman at the gate who greatly desires to speak with you.

dialogs.original: From the Count Orsino, is it?
dialogs.translated: Is he sent from Duke Orsino?

dialogs.original: I know not, madam. 'Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
dialogs.translated: I don't know, madam. He's a good-looking young man, and has some attendants with him.

dialogs.original: Who of my people hold him in delay?
dialogs.translated: Which of my people is delaying him right now?

dialogs.original: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
dialogs.translated: Sir Toby, madam, your uncle.

dialogs.original: Fetch him off, I pray you. He speaks nothing but madman.Fie on him!
dialogs.translated: Send Sir Toby away, please. He talks like a madman. Shame on him!

dialogs.original: Go you, Malvolio. If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home.   What you will, to dismiss it.
dialogs.translated: You go, Malvolio. If this visitor is a messenger from the duke, then tell him that I'm sick, or not at home. Do whatever you have to to make him go away.

dialogs.original: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.
dialogs.translated: Now you see, sir, how your jokes grow stale, and people dislike them.

dialogs.original: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool,   whose skull Jove cram with brains, forhere he comesone of thy kin has a most weak    pia mater.
dialogs.translated: Holy lady, you've spoken so highly of us foolsit's almost as if your eldest son was going to be a fool. And may God cram his skull with brains, for here comes one of your relatives whose head is quite empty.

dialogs.original: By mine honor, half-drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?
dialogs.translated: I swear, he's half-drunk. Who is that at the gate, uncle?

dialogs.original: A gentleman.
dialogs.translated: A gentleman.

dialogs.original: A gentleman? What gentleman?
dialogs.translated: A gentleman? What gentleman?

dialogs.original: 'Tis a gentleman here   a plague o' these pickle herring!    How now, sot!
dialogs.translated: There's a gentleman here[hiccoughs] Damn those pickled herring! They upset my stomach. How's it going, you drunken fool?

dialogs.original: Good Sir Toby!
dialogs.translated: Good Sir Toby!

dialogs.original: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?
dialogs.translated: Uncle, uncle, it's so early in the dayhow are you already so sick?

dialogs.original: Lechery! I defy lechery. Theres one at the gate.
dialogs.translated: Tricks? I hate tricks. There's a man at the gate.

dialogs.original: Ay, marry, what is he?
dialogs.translated: Yes, I heard, but who is he?

dialogs.original: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not. Give me faith, say I. Well, its all one.
dialogs.translated: Let him be the devil if he wants to be, I don't care. God will give me the faith to resist him. It doesn't matter to me.

dialogs.original: Whats a drunken man like, fool?
dialogs.translated: Tell me what a drunk man is like, fool.

dialogs.original: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman. One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
dialogs.translated: He's like a drowned man, a fool, and a madman. The first drink makes him a fool, the second makes him a madman, and the third drowns him.

dialogs.original: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz.   For hes in the third degree of drink, hes drowned. Go look after him.
dialogs.translated: Go and find the coroner then, and let him investigate my unclefor he's in the third degree of drunkenness, and has drowned. Go look after him.

dialogs.original: He is but mad yet, madonna, and the fool shall look to the madman.
dialogs.translated: He's still only in the second degree, my lady, so the fool will take care of the madman.

dialogs.original: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you.I told him you were sick.   He takes on him to understandso much, and therefore comes to speak with you.   I told him you were asleep. He seems to have a foreknowledge ofthat too, and therefore comes to speak with you.   What is to be said to him, lady? Hes fortified against any denial.
dialogs.translated: Madam, that young fellow out there swears that he must speak with you no matter what. I told him you were sick. He claims to know that already, and says that that's why he came to speak with you. I told him you were asleep. He claims to know that already too, and said that that's why he came to speak with you. What should I say to him, lady? He's too strong for all my excuses.

dialogs.original: Tell him he shall not speak with me.
dialogs.translated: Just tell him that he won't speak with me.

dialogs.original: He's been told so, and he says hell stand at your door like a sheriffs post, and be the supporter to a bench, but hell speak with you.
dialogs.translated: I told him that already, but he says he'll stand at your door like a signpost or the leg of a bench until he is allowed to speak with you.

dialogs.original: What kind o' man is he?
dialogs.translated: What kind of man is he?

dialogs.original: Why, of mankind.
dialogs.translated: Why, part of mankind.

dialogs.original: What manner of man?
dialogs.translated: But what is his manner?

dialogs.original: Of very ill manner. Hell speak with you, will you or no.
dialogs.translated: He has very bad manners. He says he'll speak to you whether you like it or not.

dialogs.original: Of what personage and years is he?
dialogs.translated: But what does he look like, and how old is he?

dialogs.original: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy,   as a squash is before tis a peascod, or a codling when tis almost an apple.   'Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.   He is very well-favored, andhe speaks very shrewishly.   One would think his mothersmilk were scarce out of him.
dialogs.translated: He's not yet old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy either. He's like a pea pod or an apple just before it's ripe. He's like a slack tide, caught between coming in and going outbetween boyhood and manhood. He's very good-looking, but he's nagging. It seems like he's just barely stopped breastfeeding.

dialogs.original: Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.
dialogs.translated: Let him enter. Call in my lady-in-waiting.

dialogs.original: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
dialogs.translated: Gentlewoman, my lady calls for you.

dialogs.original: Give me my veil. Come, throw it o'er my face.  [OLIVIA puts on a veil]  Well once more hear Orsinos embassy.
dialogs.translated: Give me my veil. Come, throw it over my face. [OLIVIA puts on a veil] Let's hear Orsino's offer once more.

dialogs.original: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
dialogs.translated: Which of you is the honorable lady of the house?

dialogs.original: Speak to me. I shall answer for her. Your will?
dialogs.translated: Speak to meI'll answer for her. What do you want?

dialogs.original: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beautyI pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her.   I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it.   Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn.   I am very comptible, even to the leastsinister usage.
dialogs.translated: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beautybut please, tell me if you're really the lady of the house, for I've never actually seen her. I would hate to throw away my speech on the wrong person, for it is excellently written and was very hard for me to memorize. Good beauties, please don't scorn me. I'm very sensitive, even to the slightest bit of rudeness.

dialogs.original: Whence came you, sir?
dialogs.translated: Where do you come from, sir?

dialogs.original: I can say little more than I have studied, and that questions out of my part.   Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that Imay proceed in my speech.
dialogs.translated: I can only repeat what I've memorized, and that question isn't part of my lines. Please, gentle lady, just assure me that you are the lady of the house, so I can go on with my speech.

dialogs.original: Are you a comedian?
dialogs.translated: Are you an actor?

dialogs.original: No, my profound heart. And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?
dialogs.translated: No, my dear lady. But I also swear that I'm not the same person as the part I'm playing. Are you the lady of the house?

dialogs.original: If I do not usurp myself, I am.
dialogs.translated: If I haven't stolen this role from myself, then I am.

dialogs.original: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.   Butthis is from my commission. I will on with my speech inyour praise and then show you the heart of my message.
dialogs.translated: If you are the lady of the house, then you certainly have stolen from yourself, because what's yours to give away is not yours to keep for yourself. But this isn't what I was sent to say. I'll go on with my speech praising you, and then I'll get to the heart of my message.

dialogs.original: Come to what is important in t. I forgive you the praise.
dialogs.translated: Just tell me the important part. I'll excuse you for skipping the praise.

dialogs.original: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and tis poetical.
dialogs.translated: Oh, but I worked so hard memorizing it, and it's poetic.

dialogs.original: It is the more like to be feigned. I pray you, keep it in.   I heard you were saucy at my gates and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you.   If you be not mad, be gone. If you have reason, be brief.    'Tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.
dialogs.translated: Then it's more likely to be fake. Please, keep it to yourself. I heard you were rude at my gates, and I let you in because I was curious about you, not to hear your message. If you're not crazy, then go. If you're sane, be quick. I am not in the mood for lively conversation.

dialogs.original: Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.
dialogs.translated: Will you set sail and leave now, sir? Here's the door.

dialogs.original: No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady.
dialogs.translated: No, good sailor, I'll dock here a little longer. My lady, would you call off your giant here?

dialogs.original: Tell me your mind.
dialogs.translated: Tell me what you want.

dialogs.original: I am a messenger.
dialogs.translated: I am a messenger.

dialogs.original: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when thecourtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.
dialogs.translated: Then you must have a horrible message to deliver, since you're so afraid to get to the point. Speak your business.

dialogs.original: It alone concerns your ear.   I bring no overture of war,no taxation of homage. I hold the olive in my hand   . My words are as full of peace as matter.
dialogs.translated: It only concerns you. I'm not bringing a declaration of war or a demand for praise. I'm only bringing you an olive branch. My words are full of peace.

dialogs.original: Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?
dialogs.translated: Yet you began rudely. Who are you? What do you want?

dialogs.original: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment.   What I am and what I would are assecret as maidenhead.   To your ears, divinity. To any others, profanation.
dialogs.translated: I only learned my rudeness from the way I was received here. Who I am and what I want are as secret as a girl's virginity. I have a holy message for your ears only. It would be blasphemy for anyone else to hear it.

dialogs.original: Give us the place alone. We will hear this divinity.
dialogs.translated: Everyone, leave us alone. I will hear this "holy message."

dialogs.original: Now, sir, what is your text?
dialogs.translated: Now, sir, what is your sacred text?

dialogs.original: Most sweet lady
dialogs.translated: Most sweet lady

dialogs.original: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?
dialogs.translated: This sounds like a comforting doctrine of faith, one that deserves to be spoken of. Where is the sacred text your "holy message" comes from?

dialogs.original: In Orsinos bosom.
dialogs.translated: In Orsino's heart.

dialogs.original: In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?
dialogs.translated: In his heart? In what chapter and verse of his heart?

dialogs.original: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.
dialogs.translated: To continue this metaphorin the first chapter of his heart.

dialogs.original: Oh, I have read it. It is heresy. Have you no more to say?
dialogs.translated: Oh, I have read that. It's not a holy message, it's heresy. Do you have anything more to say?

dialogs.original: Good madam, let me see your face.
dialogs.translated: Good madam, let me see your face.

dialogs.original: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text.   But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.   Look you, sir, such a one I was this present. Is t not well done?
dialogs.translated: Did your lord order you to negotiate with my face? You've gone off your script now.  But I'll draw the curtain and show you the picture. Look, sir, this is a portrait of me in this present moment. Isn't it well done?

dialogs.original: Excellently done, if God did all.
dialogs.translated: It's excellently done, if that's the way God made it.

dialogs.original: 'Tis in grain, sir. 'Twill endure wind and weather.
dialogs.translated: It's natural, sir. Wind and rain won't wash it off.

dialogs.original: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white    Natures own sweet and cunning hand laid on.    Lady, you are the cruelst she alive    If you will lead these graces to the grave    And leave the world no copy.
dialogs.translated: It's truly beautifulyour red lips and white skin painted by Nature's sweet and skillful hand. My lady, you are the cruelest woman alive if you'll let your beauty go with you to the grave, instead of having children and passing it on.

dialogs.original: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted. I will give out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labeled to my will:   as, item, two lips indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?
dialogs.translated: Oh, sir, I won't be so cruel. I'll give out lists of my beauty. I'll make a detailed inventory, with every part labeled and added to my will. For exampleitem: two lips, moderately red. Item: two grey eyes, with lids attached. Item: one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you only sent here to praise my beauty?

dialogs.original: I see you what you are, you are too proud.    But, if you were the devil, you are fair.    My lord and master loves you. Oh, such love    Could be but recompensed though you were crowned    The nonpareil of beauty.
dialogs.translated: I see what you areyou're too proud. But even if you were the devil, you'd still be beautiful. My lord and master loves you. Such love as his couldn't be repaid even if you were crowned the most beautiful woman in the world.

dialogs.original: How does he love me?
dialogs.translated: How does he love me?

dialogs.original: With adorations, fertile tears, With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.
dialogs.translated: With adoration, with abundant tears, with thunderous groans, with passionate sighs.

dialogs.original: Your lord does know my mind. I cannot love him.    Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,    Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth.    In voices well divulged, free, learned, and valiant;    And in dimension and the shape of nature    A gracious person.   But yet I cannot love him;    He might have took his answer long ago.
dialogs.translated: Your lord knows my mind. I cannot love him. I'm sure he is a virtuous man, and I know he's noble, rich, and young. Public opinion reports that he is generous, smart, and brave, both gracious in his manner and good-looking. But despite all that, I cannot love him. He should have accepted my answer long ago.

dialogs.original: If I did love you in my masters flame,    With such a suffering, such a deadly life,    In your denial I would find no sense;    I would not understand it.
dialogs.translated: If I loved you with my master's passionwith such suffering and a life that is like deathyour rejection would make no sense to me. I would not understand it.

dialogs.original: Why, what would you?
dialogs.translated: Well, what would you do if you were your master?

dialogs.original: Make me a willow cabin at your gate    And call upon my soul within the house.    Write loyal cantons of contemned love    And sing them loud even in the dead of night.    Halloo your name to the reverberate hills    And make the babbling gossip of the air    Cry out Olivia!   Oh, you should not rest    Between the elements of air and earth,    But you should pity me.
dialogs.translated: I would build a little cabin outside your gates, and from there I'd call out to you, my soul, in your house. I would write loyal songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly even in the dead of night. I would shout your name to the hills and make their echoes cry out "Olivia!" Oh, you wouldn't be able to go anywhere under the sun without pitying me.

dialogs.original: You might do much.What is your parentage?
dialogs.translated: There's a lot you would do. What rank are your parents?

dialogs.original: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.I am a gentleman.
dialogs.translated: I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman.

dialogs.original: Get you to your lord.    I cannot love him. Let him send no more    Unless perchance you come to me again    To tell me how he takes it.   Fare you well.    I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.
dialogs.translated: Go back to your lord. I cannot love him. Tell him not to send any more messengersunless, perhaps, you were to return and tell me how he takes my rejection. Farewell. Thank you for your trouble. Here is something for you to spend. [Offers VIOLA money]

dialogs.original: I am no feed post, lady. Keep your purse.    My master, not myself, lacks recompense.    Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,    And let your fervor, like my masters, be    Placed in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.
dialogs.translated: I'm no paid messenger, my lady. Keep your money. It's my master, not myself, who's going without his due reward. May the man you fall in love with have a heart of stone, and may your passion, like my master's, be scornfully rejected. Farewell, you beautiful cruelty.

dialogs.original: What is your parentage?    Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.    I am a gentleman.   Ill be sworn thou art;    Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit,    Do give thee fivefold blazon.   Not too fast! Soft, soft!    Unless the master were the man. How now?    Even so quickly may one catch the plague?    Methinks I feel this youths perfections    With an invisible and subtle stealth    To creep in at mine eyes.   Well, let it be.    What ho, Malvolio!
dialogs.translated: "What rank are your parents?" "I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman." Yes, I'll swear that you are; your words, your face, your body, your actions, and your spirit all seem like a coat of arms for a lord. But not so fast! Calm down, calm down! If only Orsino were Cesario. But what's going on? Can someone catch the plague of love this quickly? I think I can feel this youth's perfection creeping stealthily and invisibly in through my eyes. Well, let it happen. [Calling out to MALVOLIO] Come, Malvolio!

dialogs.original: Here, madam, at your service.
dialogs.translated: Here, madam, at your service.

dialogs.original: Run after that same peevish messenger,    The countys man. He left this ring behind him,    Would I or not. Tell him Ill none of it.    [OLIVIA hands him a ring]    Desire him not to flatter with his lord,    Nor hold him up with hopes.   I am not for him.    If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,    Ill give him reasons for t. Hie thee, Malvolio.
dialogs.translated: Run after that irritating messenger who just left, the duke's man. He left this ring behind, whether I wanted it or not. Tell him I want nothing to do with it. [OLIVIA hands him a ring] Tell him not to encourage Orsino, or get his hopes up. I am not for him. And tell that youth that if he'll come by tomorrow, I'll give him reasons why. Now hurry up, Malvolio.

dialogs.original: Madam, I will.
dialogs.translated: Madam, I will.

dialogs.original: I do I know not what and fear to find    Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.    Fate, show thy force. Ourselves we do not owe.    What is decreed must be, and be this so.
dialogs.translated: I don't know what I'm doing, and I'm afraid that I'm falling in love based entirely on good looksusing my eyes instead of using my head. Fate, do what you will. We can't control our destinies. What must be will be, so let it happen.
